title: Veo 3 for Developers - Paige Bailey

cleanText:
[Music]
Thank you so much for having me. Thank you all for being here today and wanting to learn more about generative media. Um, I'm going to keep this pretty quick. There's a lot to show, especially for some of the new features that we've released in V3. Um, but there's also a lot to discuss in the frame of how does this revolutionize the way that people build things? How do people create ads? Uh, and how do people replicate some of the experiences that you might see every day? Um, so as mentioned, I'm Paige. I am the engine lead for our Devrell team at Google DeepMind. Um, but I'm here today on behalf of our generative media team, who are all brilliant. Uh, they are wonderful. Tom Hume, Demetri Horn, many of them could not be here today. Um but this is all their work. So I just want to send like a thank you to the heavens for everything that they've been building. Um today we're going to be talking about three different models. So Veo 3, which is our new video and audio generation model, Imagine 4, which can generate these static images, and also LIA 2, which is a music generation model. Um and stay tuned, there will be more of all of the above coming shortly. Um, Veo is kind of magical in the sense that, you know, you can create videos of things that you've never seen before. And we've seen some of these examples already, but it also has the potential to really revolutionize everything that we build and create as humans. And I loved this quote from Andre Karpathy, just recently that video has the potential to be an incredible surface for communication, but also for education and for human creativity. So all of these things are designed with that in mind. Um V2, I just want to touch on it briefly before we get into the Veo 3 capabilities. Um we released a whole bunch of additional things around creative control just recently. So think on the order of about a month ago or not even that. Um so things like reference powered videos, outpainting, the ability to add and remove objects, character control and consistency which I think you y'all were talking about just a little while ago, and also the ability to interpolate across first and last frames. And let's take a look at what that means. Um because for people who are not necessarily filmmakers, it's much much easier to show and not tell. Um, so reference powered videos are things like you have a person, you have an environment, and you're able to kind of put one within the other or compose them together into something that feels very stylized but also like really really well crafted. Um so here you can see reference powered video with V2. This is available via the API and via some of our tools like Flow today.
Uh, and another example of reference powered video. So, a really really cute little monster in a variety of environments that you just control by describing. Um, it's performing pretty well on benchmarks. So, you can see here the green is Veo. So, compared to things like Runway Gen 4 and Cling, the more green the better. Um, and for reference powered video, most human raiders selected for Veo for some of these side-by-side comparisons. You can also match styles. Um, so upload a reference image and then have different styles composed together.
Another example of styles being preserved. And then also camera controls the same that you might have if you were a filmmaker. So things like being able to move back, move right, um rotate up, zoom in, and to be able to precisely control all of these camera movements. Again, just via natural language and through some of the tools that are available in the APIs. Um when I saw all of this, I was blown away because I don't think that we have nearly enough code samples demonstrating some of these capabilities. Um but these are all things that you can do with the V2 models today. Um with the APIs, we also have the ability to do outpainting. This was important for a recent project with the sphere around Wizard of Oz. So being able to take a scene or an individual frame of a video and imagine what the rest of the scene might look like. So even if you only have a view into a small portion, being able to create something that looks real or that looks consistent across the outpainting.
Um adding objects or removing objects from scenes. So you can see here a few examples as well. Um and again all of these available for you to test and to try today. Um, these are all things that exist that our research team has kind of gotten into the API designs. Um, some more examples of removing objects. Character control is quite nice. You might have seen some of these demonstrated into your favorite products for controlling mouth movements, controlling reference space movements for particular characters. We also give the ability to add a script and to add kind of a voice tone and to have the character map the lips to producing that sound and producing it in a way that feels consistent with the location.
